name: Great Emu War
the-point: In 1932, the Australian military 'fought' a war against emus and actually lost.

name: Voynich Manuscript
the-point: There is a 15th-century book written in an unknown language that no cryptographer can crack.

name: Dancing Plague
the-point: In 1518, hundreds of people in France danced uncontrollably for days until some died of heart attacks.

name: Ancient Batteries
the-point: The 'Baghdad Battery' suggests humans might have experimented with electricity 2,000 years ago.

name: Lost Colony
the-point: The entire colony of Roanoke vanished in 1590, leaving only the word 'Croatoan' carved on a tree.

name: Julius Caesar
the-point: Caesar was once kidnapped by pirates; he told them they should ask for a higher ransom because he was worth more.

name: Shortest War
the-point: The Anglo-Zanzibar War of 1896 lasted only 38 minutes.

name: Napoleon’s Height
the-point: Napoleon wasn't actually short; he was average height, but British propaganda spread the lie.

name: The Great Fire
the-point: The Great Fire of London in 1666 only officially killed 6 people, though it destroyed most of the city.

name: Viking Discovery
the-point: Vikings reached North America nearly 500 years before Christopher Columbus.

name: Roman Concrete
the-point: Roman concrete is more durable than modern concrete and can actually 'heal' itself when cracked.

name: Samurai in Mexico
the-point: In the 1600s, a Samurai named Hasekura Tsunenaga traveled to Mexico and Rome.

name: Dinosaur Gap
the-point: Stegosaurus lived longer before T-Rex than T-Rex lived before humans.

name: Interrupted Game
the-point: The 1914 'Christmas Truce' saw WWI soldiers stop fighting to play soccer together.

name: Mausoleum of Qin
the-point: The first Emperor of China’s tomb is surrounded by rivers of liquid mercury that still exist today.

name: Potato Laws
the-point: Potatoes were once banned in France because people thought they caused leprosy.

name: The Library of Alexandria
the-point: We probably lost thousands of years of scientific progress when the Library of Alexandria burned.

name: Albert Einstein
the-point: Einstein was offered the presidency of Israel in 1952 but turned it down.

name: Tulip Mania
the-point: In the 1630s, a single tulip bulb in Holland could cost more than a house.

name: The Silk Road
the-point: The Silk Road wasn't a road; it was a massive network of shifting sea and land routes.

name: Maya Calendar
the-point: The Mayans didn't predict the end of the world; they just ran out of space on that specific calendar cycle.

name: Pirate Democracy
the-point: Most pirate ships were democratic, with captains elected by the crew and equal shares of loot.

name: Victorian Photos
the-point: Victorians took photos with their deceased relatives as a way to remember them.

name: The Wright Brothers
the-point: The first flight lasted only 12 seconds, covering a distance shorter than the wingspan of a modern Boeing 747.

name: Ice Age Survival
the-point: Humans survived the last Ice Age primarily by following the migration of mammoths.
